questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 2-month-old girl is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-day history of fever and difficulty breathing. Her mother says that she has had nasal congestion for 2 days. She was born at 28 weeks' gestation and weighed 1105 g (2 lb 7 oz); she currently weighs 2118 g (4 lb 11 oz). Her neonatal course was complicated by respiratory distress syndrome. She required supplemental oxygen for 36 days following birth. She was diagnosed with bronchopulmonary dysplasia 3 weeks ago. Her mother says the girl missed an appointment with the pediatrician 2 weeks ago. Her father has a peanut allergy and a dust mite allergy. Her maternal grandfather died of heart failure. Her only medication is vitamin D drops. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.4°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/45 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 87%. Physical examination shows moderate subcostal retractions. Wheezing is heard on auscultation of the chest. Her hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 13,000/mm3, and platelet count is 345,000/mm3. A decision is made to initiate mechanic ventilatory support. After 4 days in the pediatric intensive care unit, the patient dies. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's outcome?
questions.render_hint: Based on the patient's medical history and examination findings, she most likely had bronchiolitis. Bronchiolitis is usually caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), which primarily affects children < 2 years of age and causes symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection followed by respiratory distress (e.g., intercostal or subcostal retractions, wheezing).

a.walk_why: Postnatal glucocorticoid therapy has been shown to improve outcomes with regards to bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) for infants born prematurely. However, it has also been shown to have short and long-term adverse effects, including hyperglycemia, hypertension, GI bleeding, and possibly an increase in the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disabilities. The revised 2010 American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) guidelines therefore recommend against its use in preventing BPD. It may be considered in infants with severe BPD who require persistent ventilatory support, which was not the case in this child.

b.walk_why: Respiratory syncytial virus immune globulin is a polyclonal immune globulin formerly used in the prophylaxis of RSV infection. As a blood product prepared from donor serum, it had the potential to be contaminated. Its use was also associated with increased morbidity and mortality in patients with congenital heart disease. For these reasons, it was replaced by a safer alternative and is no longer available.
b.walk_but: In the past, RSV prophylaxis would have been indicated in this infant, who was born prematurely and had bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

c.walk_why: Ribavirin is an antiviral synthetic nucleoside analog that can be used to treat RSV. It is currently not recommended for routine treatment, and should only be considered for immunocompromised patients, which this patient was not.

d.walk_why: Ceftriaxone is a 3rd-generation cephalosporin, a β-lactam antibiotic that inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used in the treatment of bacterial infections like meningitis and disseminated Lyme disease. Bronchiolitis is usually caused by a virus (RSV), not bacteria, rendering ceftriaxone ineffective in this case.

e.walk_why: Palivizumab is a short-acting monoclonal antibody that provides passive immunity to bronchiolitis caused by RSV. It functions by binding to RSV and inhibiting fusion and uptake of the virus into cells. According to current guidelines, it is only recommended for infants at risk for severe bronchiolitis (e.g., those with prematurity, heart or lung disease). This patient presented with the classic features of RSV bronchiolitis, was born prematurely, and had bronchopulmonary dysplasia, fulfilling the criteria for palivizumab prophylaxis.
e.walk_but: In order to provide adequate protection for patients at risk, palivizumab must be administered by intramuscular (IM) injection on a monthly basis during RSV season for the first year of life.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, fever, body aches, headache, and sore throat for 1 week. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is sexually active with one female partner and they use condoms consistently. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Examination shows enlarged, erythematous, and exudative tonsils, as well as palatal petechiae and bilateral posterior auricular lymphadenopathy. The spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 11500/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 52%
Band forms 2%
Basophils 0.5%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 41%
Monocytes 3.5%
Serum
Heterophile antibody test positive

Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.render_hint: This patient's presentation of fever, fatigue, myalgia/arthralgia, headache, and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy are consistent with both infectious mononucleosis and mononucleosis-like syndrome. However, splenomegaly, lymphocytosis, and the positive heterophile agglutination (Monospot test) indicate infectious mononucleosis (IM) as the cause of his symptoms.

a.walk_why: IM is caused by Epstein-Barr virus (human herpes virus 4) and it typically affects individuals younger than 30 years of age. Transmission frequently occurs via saliva ("kissing disease"). Clinical suspicion of IM is confirmed with a monospot test, which uses RBCs from horses to detect heterophile antibodies produced in response to Epstein-Barr virus infection. Treatment is symptomatic.
a.walk_but: EBV is also an onchogenic virus that can rarely cause Burkitt's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, or oral hairy leukoplakia.

b.walk_why: Acute human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection often presents as a mononucleosis-like syndrome, but this patient has no reported risk factors for HIV infection (e.g., several sexual partners, inconsistent use of condoms) and the diagnosis of IM has already been established.

c.walk_why: Cytomegalovirus (human herpes virus 5) infection may present as a mononucleosis-like syndrome, but more than 90% of affected individuals remain asymptomatic. Regardless, CMV is not the cause of IM.

d.walk_why: Streptococcus pyogenes (group A streptococci) may cause acute tonsillitis, which is characterized by fever, sore throat, dysphagia, a swollen pharynx, tonsillar exudates, and painful cervical lymphadenopathy. Although the presentation in this case is similar to that of acute tonsillitis, the diagnosis of IM has already been established.

e.walk_why: Toxoplasmosis is a disease caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii. Transmission occurs through ingestion of cysts present in, for example, raw meat or cat feces. It may present with mononucleosis-like symptoms, especially in immunocompetent patients. But the vignette does not mention any risk factors for acquiring toxoplasmosis, and a diagnosis of IM has already been established.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a cough for 2 days. The cough occurs as paroxysmal spells, with vomiting sometimes occurring afterwards. She takes a deep breath after these spells that makes a “whooping” sound. She has been unable to sleep well because of the cough. She had a runny nose and low-grade fever 1 week ago. She was admitted at the age of 9 months for bronchiolitis. Her immunizations are incomplete, as her parents are afraid of vaccine-related complications. She attends a daycare center but there have been no other children who have similar symptoms. She appears well. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 41,000/mm3, platelet count is 230,000/mm3 and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 31 mm/hr. An X-ray of the chest is unremarkable. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.render_hint: Paroxysmal coughing spells followed by an inspiratory whoop and occasional vomiting is typical for pertussis and goes hand in hand with increased intra-alveolar pressure!

a.walk_why: Pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardium that presents with chest pain and dyspnea. It is most commonly idiopathic or caused by viruses but can also occur in association with bacterial infections, neoplasms, collagen-vascular diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus), certain drugs (e.g., doxorubicin), radiation, trauma, or following acute myocardial infarction. However, Bordetella pertussis, the pathogen that causes pertussis, is not known to cause pericarditis.

b.walk_why: Hemolytic anemia is a condition characterized by the increased destruction of red blood cells and presents with jaundice and dark urine in addition to signs of anemia. The disease can be hereditary (e.g., sickle cell disease) or acquired (e.g., in association with infections). Known infectious causes of hemolytic anemia include Mycoplasma species and Clostridium perfringens. Bordetella pertussis, the pathogen that causes whooping cough, however, is not associated with hemolytic anemia.
b.walk_but: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia (also for children). Patients typically present with a nonproductive cough and a low-grade fever. Diagnostic evaluation shows diffuse reticular opacities on chest X-ray. Atypical pneumonia is an important differential diagnosis and should be considered in this patient. However, the typical cough with a “whooping” sound makes pertussis more likely.

c.walk_why: Guillain-Barré syndrome is an immune-mediated neurological disorder that presents with progressive ascending paralysis. It most commonly occurs as a sequela of Campylobacter jejuni gastroenteritis but can present in association with other infections such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, cytomegalovirus, or Epstein-Barr virus infection. Pertussis, however, is not associated with this condition.

d.walk_why: Hemoptysis is coughing up blood from the lower respiratory tract. It can be caused by a variety of conditions, including infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis), autoimmune diseases (e.g., Goodpasture syndrome), cardiac diseases (e.g., congestive heart failure), toxins (e.g., cocaine use), or airway trauma. Pertussis, however, is not a likely cause of hemoptysis.

e.walk_why: Pneumothorax is the accumulation of air within the pleural space that presents with sudden chest pain and dyspnea. Pertussis (whooping cough) is usually associated with severe bouts of coughing, leading to increased intrathoracic and intra-abdominal pressure and a subsequent risk of complications such as scleral hemorrhages, epistaxis, abdominal hernias, and pneumothorax. Other, more common complications of pertussis include apnea and secondary infections (e.g., otitis media).
e.walk_but: The pertussis vaccination is recommended for all children at 2, 4, 6, and 15–18 months, as well as 4–6 years and is routinely administered together with the diphtheria and tetanus vaccine (DTaP). The incidence of pertussis has significantly decreased since the introduction of the vaccine in the 1940s. However, there has been a steady increase in incidence over the past 40 years and epidemics occur every 2–5 years in the US. The reason for the recent increase in incidence is not fully understood but may be due to factors such as more sensitive diagnostic tests, decreased use of the pertussis vaccine, and genetic changes in the strains of pertussis.

f.walk_why: Asthma is an obstructive lung disease with a complex etiology that presents with attacks of dyspnea, coughing, and chest pain. Respiratory tract infections, allergens, and exercise can all trigger acute asthma attacks in genetically predisposed individuals. Childhood risk factors for persistent asthma include atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, food allergies, and bronchiolitis requiring hospitalizations. While the patient’s history of hospitalization for bronchiolitis puts her at an increased risk of developing asthma, it is not a complication of pertussis.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of shortness of breath and swollen extremities for 2 weeks. He has had excessive night sweats and a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the last 4 weeks. He had an anterior myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He immigrated from Taiwan 3 months ago. He works in a shipyard. His older brother has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin, aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol, and ramipril. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 46.7 kg (103 lb); BMI is 18.2 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/95 mm Hg. Examination shows generalized pitting edema. There is jugular vein distention, hepatomegaly, and a paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration. Chest x-ray shows bilateral pleural effusion, patchy infiltrates in the right middle lobe, and pericardial thickening and calcifications. Laboratory studies show:

Serum
Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL
Urine
Blood negative
Glucose negative
Protein 1+

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.render_hint: Generalized pitting edema, jugular venous distention, paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration (Kussmaul's sign), and pericardial calcifications are all suggestive of constrictive pericarditis. What is the most likely etiology in this recently immigrated patient with night sweats and weight loss?

a.walk_why: Uremia is the excess of urea nitrogen in the blood, typically caused by chronic kidney disease. Severe uremia may affect the heart, causing fibrinous pericarditis. This patient has pericarditis; however, this patient’s urea nitrogen is only marginally elevated, making uremia as the explanation for this patient’s symptoms unlikely.

b.walk_why: Myocarditis is inflammation of the heart muscle most commonly caused by viruses. Acute viral myocarditis is typically a sequela of a viral upper respiratory infection and may lead to concurrent inflammation of the pericardium. Although this patient’s shortness of breath and fever may point to myocarditis, this patient does not have any chest pain or cardiac arrhythmias, which are typical findings in myocarditis. Additionally, pericardial thickening and calcifications suggest chronic pericarditis.

c.walk_why: Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease that results from exposure to asbestos fibers. Although this patient’s occupation as a shipyard worker may suggest possible exposure to asbestos fibers, the absence of cough and interstitial fibrosis on imaging make this diagnosis unlikely.

d.walk_why: Amyloidosis is characterized by the build-up of abnormal protein fibers in various tissues. In the heart, amyloidosis causes restrictive cardiomyopathy, presenting with signs of diastolic heart failure. This patient, however, has a paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration, which is a sign of systolic heart failure. The findings of dyspnea, jugular venous distention, and hepatomegaly may suggest heart failure, but amyloidosis would not explain the night sweats and the pericardial thickening.

e.walk_why: Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease affecting the metabolism of glucose. Complications of diabetes mellitus include diabetic nephropathy, which may present with peripheral and pulmonary edema in cases of nephrotic-range proteinuria. However, the laboratory values only suggest mild kidney damage, and diabetes mellitus would not explain the findings of jugular venous distention and the positive Kussmaul’s sign.

f.walk_why: Postmyocardial infarction syndrome, also known as Dressler’s syndrome, is an immune-mediated inflammation of the pericardium that usually occurs 1–8 weeks after myocardial infarction. Although this patient presents with pericarditis, the occurrence of it 3 years after this patient’s myocardial infarction would be very unusual. While this diabetic patient may have recently experienced a second, asymptomatic (“silent”) myocardial infarction, pericardial calcifications and patchy infiltrations in a lung make another underlying etiology more likely.

g.walk_why: Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. In a patient who recently immigrated from Taiwan, the symptoms of shortness of breath and night sweats and the findings of low-grade fever and patchy infiltrations in the right lung are highly suspicious for tuberculosis. Tuberculosis may affect any organ, including the heart, and is the most common cause of constrictive pericarditis in developing countries.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided facial weakness that he noticed after waking up. A month ago, he also experienced right-sided neck pain and headache that began after returning from a hunting trip to New Hampshire the week before. He took ibuprofen to relieve symptoms, which subsided a week later. He has a 5-year history of hypertension controlled with drug therapy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and he drinks two beers daily. His vital signs are within the normal range. Physical examination shows right-sided drooping of the upper and lower half of the face. The patient has difficulties smiling and he is unable to close his right eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.render_hint: The patient is presenting with unilateral facial paralysis, also referred to as Bell's palsy. Bell's palsy is often idiopathic but has a variety of serious causes that should be investigated. In this case, given the recent hunting trip to New Hampshire, a Lyme-endemic area, and the symptoms of unilateral neck pain and headache that followed, this patient must be tested for Lyme disease.

a.walk_why: Lumbar puncture (LP) and CSF analysis is used in cases of suspected Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), multiple sclerosis (MS), and meningitis. GBS is detected via CSF analysis and may also lead to facial paralysis. However, it is preceded by asymmetric distal muscle weakness that progresses proximally, which is not present in this patient. Meningitis typically presents with more acute symptoms, including fever, headache, and neck stiffness, none of which are present in this patient. MS can present with Bell’s palsy if an intranuclear lesion is present, but the typical MS patient is a young woman with episodes of retrobulbar neuritis, as well as oculomotor and/or sensory deficits, followed by periods of remission. Although Lyme disease can result in abnormal CSF findings, an LP is an invasive test and therefore not the ideal first step in diagnosis. It would be more appropriate after other tests were found to be inconclusive.
a.walk_but: CSF findings in Lyme disease include signs of lymphocytic meningitis (elevated protein and pleocytosis). Intrathecal Borrelia-specific IgG and IgM antibodies can be detected via immunoblot.

b.walk_why: ELISA is the first test performed in two‑step serological testing for Lyme disease. It serves as a screening test and, if positive, is followed by Western blot for confirmation. This patient is suffering from unilateral facial paralysis that does not spare the forehead. This type of facial paralysis (sometimes referred to as Bell’s palsy) indicates an ipsilateral lower motor neuron lesion (i.e., a problem localized in the peripheral nerve rather than the motor cortex), and has various etiologies, including infections (frequently Lyme disease or herpes zoster; rarely HIV or Guillain-Barré syndrome), iatrogenic factors, trauma, metabolic conditions, and tumors. In approx. 80% of cases of Bell’s palsy, no underlying medical condition is found, but this patient’s presentation is strongly suggestive of Lyme disease, and a screening test is indicated.

c.walk_why: Western blot is the second test performed in two‑step serological testing for Lyme disease. It is also used as a confirmatory test in HIV diagnosis. This patient is suffering from unilateral facial paralysis that does not spare the forehead (sometimes referred to as Bell’s palsy), and has various etiologies, including infections (frequently Lyme disease or herpes zoster, rarely HIV or Guillain-Barré syndrome), iatrogenic factors, trauma, metabolic conditions, and tumors. In approx. 80% of cases of Bell’s palsy, no underlying medical condition is found, but this patient’s presentation is strongly suggestive of Lyme disease, and a screening test is indicated.
c.walk_but: A Western blot can be used to detect IgG and IgM antibodies against Borrelia.

d.answer: Polymerase chain reaction of the facial skin
d.walk_why: PCR of the facial skin may be used to detect various pathogens, including varicella zoster virus (VZV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV). Reactivation of VZV in herpes zoster oticus is the cause of Ramsay Hunt syndrome, a condition that does cause ipsilateral facial paralysis. However, the pain and herpetic skin vesicles characteristic of VZV reactivation are not present in this patient. Reactivation of HSV is thought to be the cause of the majority of cases of Bell’s palsy; however, this patient’s history of neck pain and headache 1 month ago following a trip to the Northeast makes another diagnosis more likely. A screening test for Lyme disease should be performed first.

e.walk_why: Noncontrast CT would be the test of choice if stroke were suspected. Given this patient’s history of smoking and hypertension, as well as the morning presentation, ischemic stroke should be considered. An intranuclear lesion caused by stroke could potentially lead to unilateral facial paralysis that does not spare the forehead (also referred to as Bell’s palsy), but it would typically be accompanied by brachiofacial symptoms. However, this patient developed Bell’s palsy following a history of pain in the area and after a trip to a Lyme-endemic area (i.e., the Northeast). Considered together, these factors make Lyme disease more likely. A screening test for Lyme disease is the next best step.
e.walk_but: If a patient presented with these risk factors (smoking and hypertension) and morning occurrence of facial paralysis sparing the forehead (i.e., probable upper motor neuron lesion) accompanied by additional brachiofacial symptoms, a noncontrast CT would be the best initial diagnostic step.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an animal bite. He was hiking earlier that day when he was bitten by a raccoon. He says the attack was unprovoked and the animal ran away after the encounter. He was bitten by a stray dog when he was 11 years old and received postexposure prophylaxis for rabies at that time. His immunizations are up-to-date. His immunization record shows he received 3 doses of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine as a child and a tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccination at the age of 16. He is in no apparent distress. His temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/75 mm Hg. He has a wound on his left lower extremity with actively bleeding puncture sites. The wound is thoroughly irrigated with normal saline and cleansed with antiseptic and a bandage is applied. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

a.walk_why: Even patients who have been vaccinated against rabies should be treated after being bitten by an animal that is a known wild reservoir for the virus.

b.walk_why: Rabies vaccination is given as standalone postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in patients who have previously received the rabies vaccine. Since this patient already received rabies PEP (which consisted of both the rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin) at the age of 11, he should only receive the vaccine at this time. He was bitten in an unprovoked attack by an animal known to be a wild reservoir for rabies. In addition to wound cleaning and consideration of tetanus and antibiotic prophylaxis, rabies PEP is very important.

c.walk_why: Rabies immunoglobulin and vaccine constitute the rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for individuals who have not previously received the vaccine. However, this patient already received rabies PEP at the age of 11, which means he should only receive a simplified PEP regimen this time.

d.walk_why: A tetanus booster with Td or Tdap would only be indicated if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient. Additionally, even patients who have been vaccinated against rabies should be treated after being bitten by an animal that is a known wild reservoir for the virus.

e.walk_why: Rabies immunoglobulin plus vaccine constitute the rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for individuals who have not previously received the vaccine. Active tetanus immunization with Td (tetanus, diphtheria) or Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis) would be indicated if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient.

f.walk_why: Rabies vaccination is given as standalone postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in patients who have previously received the rabies vaccine, as this patient has. But active tetanus immunization with Td or Tdap would only be indicated if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient.

g.walk_why: Rabies immunoglobulin is part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP), but it is generally administered with the rabies vaccine. Immunoglobulin alone is not a sufficient prophylaxis.

h.walk_why: Rabies immunoglobulin is part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP), but it is generally administered with the rabies vaccine. This patient already received rabies PEP at the age of 11 and should receive a simplified PEP regimen this time. Active tetanus immunization with Td or Tdap would be indicated if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of high-grade fever and headache for 5 days. The headache is constant and feels like a tight band around his head. The patient has had generalized fatigue and nausea for 4 days. He also reports that his eyes hurt while looking at bright lights. He has been taking acetaminophen and using cold towels to help relieve his symptoms. He works as an assistant for a nature camp organization, but has been unable to go to work for 3 days. His immunization records are unavailable. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 108/74 mm Hg. He is oriented to time, place, and person. There is no rash or lymphadenopathy. Flexion of the neck results in flexion of the knee and hip. A lumbar puncture is done; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows an opening pressure of 80 mm H20, erythrocyte count of 25/mm3, leukocyte count of 93/mm3 (78% lymphocytes), a glucose concentration of 64 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 50 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.render_hint: This patient presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and a positive Brudzinski sign (flexion of the neck results in flexion of the knee and hip). Together with a moderately raised leukocyte count with predominantly lymphocytes, slightly raised protein and normal glucose concentrations in the cerebrospinal fluid indicate aseptic meningitis.

a.walk_why: Coxsackie virus, a nonenveloped picornavirus, may cause carditis, herpangina, and hand, foot, and mouth disease. Coxsackie virus is also a common cause of aseptic (viral) meningitis. This patient has CSF findings associated with a viral etiology, which favors an infection with coxsackie virus. Clinical features of viral and bacterial meningitis are very similar. However, bacterial meningitis has a highly acute course and can be fatal within hours or days, whereas viral meningitis generally has a less acute onset and is usually self-limiting within 7–10 days. Lumbar puncture followed by cerebrospinal fluid analysis (CSF) helps to differentiate between different etiologies of meningitis.
a.walk_but: Gram staining of the CSF is negative in viral meningitis, hence the name “aseptic” meningitis.

b.walk_why: Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative diplococci, may lead to meningitis, meningococcemia, and Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome. Neisseria meningitidis is also the second most common cause of bacterial meningitis in individuals 6–60 years of age. Based on the patient’s age and clinical features alone, he may have meningitis of a bacterial origin. However, cerebrospinal fluid findings in bacterial meningitis are typically characterized by increased protein, decreased glucose, and significant granulocytosis, which make the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis unlikely in this patient.

c.walk_why: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can either be an oral (HSV-1) or a genital (HSV-2) type. HSV-1 may lead to stomatitis, herpes labialis, keratoconjunctivitis, and herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE), whereas HSV-2 predominantly causes herpes genitalis. HSE typically presents with a prodrome of headaches and fever, followed by sudden focal neurological deficits and altered mental status. Although the patient’s cerebrospinal fluid findings are consistent with meningitis of a viral origin, he does not present with focal neurological deficits, seizures, altered mental status, or behavioral changes, which make the diagnosis of HSE less likely.

d.walk_why: Borrelia burgdorferi, a spirochete, is transmitted to humans by ticks and causes Lyme disease. Lyme disease typically starts with an erythema migrans, which is followed by neurological symptoms (e.g., facial palsy), migratory arthralgia, and cardiac manifestations (e.g., myocarditis). Late disease is characterized by chronic arthritis and late neuroborreliosis with possible progressive encephalomyelitis and aseptic meningitis. The patient’s cerebrospinal fluid findings are compatible with a Borrelia burgdorferi infection. However, the patient has no history of a rash, arthritis, or cranial nerve involvement (facial palsy), which makes Lyme disease less likely.
d.walk_but: Advanced stages of Lyme disease can also cause aseptic meningitis.

e.walk_why: Streptococcus pneumoniae, a gram-positive diplococci, may lead to otitis media, sinusitis, and community-acquired pneumonia. It is also the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in individuals 6–60 years of age. Based on the patient’s age and clinical features, he may have meningitis of a bacterial origin. However, cerebrospinal fluid findings in bacterial meningitis are typically characterized by increased protein, decreased glucose, and significant granulocytosis, which make the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis unlikely in this patient.

f.walk_why: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, an acid-fast gram-positive bacilli, causes tuberculosis that commonly affects the lung. It can also disseminate and may lead to an infection of the meninges, tuberculous meningitis. Based on the patient’s clinical features alone, he may have tuberculous meningitis. However, cerebrospinal fluid findings in tuberculous meningitis are typically characterized by pleocytosis (not only lymphocytes, but also granulocytes and mononuclear cells). Furthermore, the patient lacks risk factors for having a tuberculous infection (no previous history of exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis; the patient is not from a country in which tuberculosis is endemic), which make the diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis less likely.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother after she noticed multiple painless, nonpruritic papules on her abdomen. The child attends daycare three times per week, and this past week one child was reported to have similar lesions. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her brother had chickenpox one month ago. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several flesh-colored, non-tender, pearly papules with central umbilication on the abdomen and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.render_hint: The patient’s lesions are typical of those caused by a poxvirus.

a.walk_why: Keratoacanthoma is a low-grade tumor that commonly affects the elderly. It grows rapidly (within 2–3 months) in areas of skin exposed to the sun. Examinations show a round erythematous nodule with central crater. Based on the patient’s age (2 years old), the description of the skin lesions, and the recent onset of the lesions, this patient most likely has a different underlying pathology.

b.walk_why: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin that is characterized by different types of lesions involving the skin and mucosa in individuals between 30–60 years of age. The most common lesions are plaques or papules that are pruritic, polygonal, planar (flat-topped), and purple (the 6 P´s), which typically occur on the wrists, lower extremities, and genitoanal region. Pattern of white lines on the lesion’s surface (Wickham’s striae) may also be seen. However, the skin lesions in this case are flesh-colored and they do not have irregular borders or Wickham’s striae, which makes the diagnosis of cutaneous lichen planus unlikely.

c.walk_why: In the case of insect bites (e.g., mosquito or flea), lesions are typically pruritic and physical examination most often reveals erythematous papules at the site of the bite. The patient does not have any of these findings, which makes the diagnosis of insect bites less likely.

d.walk_why: Verruca vulgaris (common warts) are caused by human papilloma virus (HPV). They are rough, scaly papules or plaques that may sometimes have a cauliflower-like appearance. They are typically located on the hands, feet, and knees. However, the patient’s skin lesions are pearly papules with a central umbilication and they are located on the abdomen, allowing verruca vulgaris to be ruled out.

e.walk_why: Molluscum contagiosum is a common localized skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus (a DNA poxvirus) that typically affects children < 5 years of age. The lesions are nontender, flesh-colored, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. They are usually 2–5 mm in diameter and commonly occur on the trunk, face, and genitalia. Because spontaneous remission usually occurs within 6–9 months, treatment is often unnecessary.
e.walk_but: Molluscum contagiosum also occurs in adults, particularly in those with immunosuppression (e.g., HIV) and/or if it has been sexually transmitted.

f.walk_why: Folliculitis is a localized inflammation of the hair follicle or sebaceous glands. It is primarily caused by Staphylococcus aureus and it is characterized by erythema, tender papules, and/or pustules at the site of hair follicles. However, the patient’s papules are non-tender and the vignette does not mention any association with hair follicles.

g.walk_why: Chickenpox (varicella) is an infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) that occurs most frequently during childhood. It presents with a rash that is characterized by the simultaneous manifestation of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts. The rash starts on the trunk, spreading to the face, scalp, and extremities and causing severe pruritus and fever. However, the patient’s rash is not pruritic and she does not have any further symptoms, which makes the diagnosis of chickenpox unlikely.
g.walk_but: As the name indicates, the VZV is also responsible for Herpes zoster (shingles) following virus reactivation, which would present with pain and a subsequent strip of vesicular erruption along a dermatome. Reactivation is generally triggered by immunosuppression and is most common in the elderly.

questions.subject: OB/Gyn
questions.render_question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of yellow vaginal discharge, pruritus, and pain with urination for the past 6 days. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis that was treated with a 10-day course of amoxicillin. She has been sexually active with multiple male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently; she has been taking an oral contraceptive for the past 2 years. She has no previous history of serious illness or sexually transmitted diseases. The patient drinks alcohol on the weekends and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily since she was 15 years old. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vulva and vagina and foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.8. Bimanual examination is unremarkable. Further evaluation of this patient’s vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.render_hint: Based on the prior antibiotic use, multiple sexual partners and the characteristic description of the vaginal discharge with an elevated pH value, this patient most likely has trichomoniasis.

a.walk_why: The whiff test is performed by adding potassium hydroxide to a mount containing vaginal discharge. It is positive if the test produces a fishy odor, which is highly characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. Unlike in this patient, bacterial vaginosis usually presents as a white or grey-colored discharge without any vulvovaginal erythema.
a.walk_but: The discharge in bacterial vaginosis also features an alkaline pH!

b.walk_why: Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, motile protozoan with flagella. Patients typically have foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green, purulent vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5. Transmission of this disease occurs through unprotected sex. Most patients remain asymptomatic.

c.walk_why: Pseudohyphae are loosely filamentous forms of fungi assumed by many yeasts, particularly Candida albicans, during growth. They are commonly seen on wet mounts of patients with vaginal yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis), which are associated with odorless white, crumbly, and sticky vaginal discharge that may resemble cottage cheese. Pregnancy, antibiotic use, and immunosuppression are predisposing factors for vaginal thrush. Even though this patient had a course of amoxicillin, her discharge is foul-smelling and yellow-green, making a candidal infection very unlikely.

d.walk_why: Chlamydia is an obligate intracellular bacterium and the most common cause of sexually transmitted bacterial disease worldwide. Infection with chlamydia is often asymptomatic. If symptoms appear, they typically include (muco)purulent endocervical discharge and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding, which this patient lacks. Furthermore, physical examination of the cervix often causes bleeding, whereas the bimanual examination of this patient was unremarkable.

e.walk_why: Gram-negative diplococci indicate infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonorrhea). The disease is transmitted sexually and is usually asymptomatic in women. If symptoms arise, they typically include purulent, creamy vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding but no erythema of the vulva.
